Hi! This is my original comment:
Complex, painless, themeless.

The games I don't get intrigue me, they are elusive, they involve people in such a way that produces unpredictable outcomes (emergant). This is not such a game. There is no theme worth naming such, there is no interaction - you're just staring at your own board (okay, yes, there's rich interaction which involves grabbing a tile from the market before someone else does).

What this is: a spatial puzzle you must solve by managing random elements and special powers of some tiles. That's all of it. And it manifests as a victory point salad, which seems to me like laziness on designer's part. Or it's just another step from conflict into the friendly euro zone when you get instant gratification for nothing.

It's a sissy game.
Which means it tries very hard to hide the fact that it is indeed a game.

And I realised I was giving some colder Uwe Rosenberg's design hard time unjustifiably. Uwe's game have focus and even in their prussian coldness, they're charming in that old german way. This has no focus (victory point salad) and no charm either. It's that aunt that let you eat everything you wanted and you didn't end up any better for it.
Later comment:

Back in the day people were talking about euros again and some guy called Feld and something called "a victory point salad". Of course, me being clever, I was sure what they're talking about. Then I played Burgund von Burgund and ... Oh! A realization dawned. So that's a victory point salad! It's not about points at all, I mean, yes it's about points from everywhere, but it's not the points that matter (they're everywhere!), but the dilution of tension. I couldn't have imagined that even the tiny amount of tension and interaction in workerplacements could be diluted further. But hey, if anybody could do it, Feld's your man. (He's also the man to make an auction be about optimisation, but that's another game).
But what you really want to read is this: Item for GeekList "Worst. Game. Ever."

On your turn, you roll two dice and use their faces to draw tiles from matching lots, play tiles to matching lots on a player board, 'sell' matching sets of goods, or buy 'workers' (essentially just a pip of die roll mitigation). Some tiles give you points; some give you points if paired with other tiles; some give you extra semi-turns; some give you workers; some let you take goods; etc.. You get extra points if you complete sections on your player board.

The game offers a neat puzzle with potential for satisfying combos, and many varying routes to victory. In a small way, you can cobble together an engine for stronger turns. But fundamentally, you play a tensionless solo puzzle with plenty of downtime wherein you manage dozens of fiddly bits featuring barely visible imagery in dreary colours and an absent theme in order to build a completely charmless tableau. The game represents everything I abhor in this hobby. Hate-drafting rarely feels possible and when it does, it normally means setting yourself back. The game plays very smoothly, and puzzle-lovers seem to find it especially stimulating. I don't find myself actively wishing for meteor impact during play, but I would happily never think about this game again.

I was unfairly predisposed to be wary of the name "Stefan Feld", one possessive consonant away from the local psychiatric ward and the kind of insensitive jokes you can imagine. Also, the designer had become popular for victory point salads and multiplayer solitaire, admittedly as-far-away-from-my-thing as it gets. Still, I got eventually curious to fix that gap in my board gaming education, and it was easy enough to find someone willing to play The Castles of Burgundy, a more-than-a-decade-old game in a BGG top 20 that was otherwise increasingly biassed towards the cult of the new.

This went both better and worse than I expected.

For all the advertisement of a mid-heavy Eurogame game and the sheer amount of setup, CoB follows a pretty simple structure: roll a couple dice, then use each die to pick/build/sell a thing that matches the die result or trade the die for a bunch of die result modifier tokens for future use. Then it's just an exercise in checking the player aid for understanding what the beige buildings do and the rulebook for the yellow tiles. The action economy is pretty simple: it normally takes two actions to place anything on the scoring part of your tableau, so try to find ways to have it only take one action, and figure out how much you're ready to spend resources prioritising a boatload of ways to make victory points.

I clearly do understand why the game has a large public, and that it's satisfying to slot a shape of the correct colour into a shape of the correct colour to complete an entire coloured area that then poops a bunch of VPs to signify you did well and got dibs on that colour. I just don't find that attaching an optimisation puzzle and a Pavlovian reward to match-the-colours is enough to sustain my interest: I'm here to play with other people, not to play with myself with other people! And on that department, The Castles of Burgundy is infuriating, because it contains just enough pretence of player interaction that people will defend (out of a sincere belief) that it's actually a genuine multiplayer game; but actually whether you get to calls dibs on a highly desired tile (say, an early silver mine) has almost nothing to do with your opponents’ position (they'll snatch it on the first reasonable opportunity), and almost everything to do with the amount of resources you'll be willing to spend to do so if the dice don't go your way. So, you know, other players are merely a randomising gizmo for your moves.

Overall, made me feel like I was playing an overcomplicated version of Kingdomino. Good for those who genuinely enjoy the complication.

This game is so well-known that I will not cover how it plays. I will straight go to what I think it does well and what I dislike about it.

The Castles of Burgundy is a typical eurogame with your own player boards, the solo puzzle that you are trying to solve and its very abstract theme. And there you have my dislikes: no interaction, an optimisation puzzle and too abstract for my liking. It overstayed its welcome by about two rounds. I was minmaxing all my moves towards the end.

Still, playing it was a soothing experience. The planning of where to place which tiles and when. Using modifiers and special abilities to shape the solution to your puzzle. It sure did tickle an intellectual itch, the same way solving a Sudoku puzzle does to me.

The Castles of Burgundy is a pure eurogame and a very satisfying one at that. There is a time and place for this type of game, which means for me: once a year at most.

A Euro game that sands off any of the sharper edges that might make it exciting in any way, shape or form. There's little meaningful interaction, or exciting hook other than, I suppose, the ephemeral dopamine hit every time you get nudged up on the victory point track (a feeling I've become numb to in gaming unless it's accompanied by real, in-game tension). The art is a frequent target for criticism here, but for me, the feeling of the gameplay matches the muted beige tones throughout the components, and it's THAT which makes me indifferent. I can look at the design and admire its clockwork elegance. That doesn't mean it will excite me, though.

I also don't dislike all Feld games. I quite enjoy one due to its higher levels of interaction. And a couple others are quite decent. Why Burgundy is his most renowned is a bit of a mystery to me. It has less of a statement to make—mechanically or narratively—than nearly any other game I can think of that's rated as highly.

My first Feld, and it was as dull and unwieldy as I expected it to be.

The premise is deceptively simple - on each turn, roll 2 dice to get two action points values that you can then spend on acquiring tiles to your hand, placing tiles from your hand into your personal tableau, acquiring die modifiers, or selling goods tiles you may have accumulated during the game.

From this basic setup, Feld gives you a veritable buffet of point sources to choose from - tiles upon tiles upon tiles replete with a plethora of icons and powers that are impossible to keep track of without a glossary, let alone learn how to ‘combo’ effectively in the manner the designer intended unless you’ve played the game dozens of times.

Since each player’s tableau is so busy and convoluted, there’s little-to-no possibility of actually peering at your opponents’, attempt to parse theirs’ and engage in any sort of meaningful player interaction. You’re far too wrapped up in your own little puzzle of understanding and optimizing the combos in your own tableau.

At the end of the day, this was a classic Euro that promised little, and delivered even less.

For many years I thought I didn't like Stefan Feld, until I realized that I did like Castles of Burgundy...and Notre Dame...and In the Year of the Dragon. So while I'm not a particular fan, I've found a niche for his particular German design style. CoB isn't my favorite by him (that is likely In the Year of the Dragon), but is definitely the best one to start with. It's a more laid-back experience, and gives off lots of fun rewards for all the little ways to score points. You feel like you are always doing SOMEthing, which is more than can be said for Dragon or Notre Dame. It's also a good two-player experience, which makes me wonder why there are comparatively few Eurogames that fill that niche.

Anyway, Feld really cracked something open here in how he uses dice. Games like this often struggle with a massive number of options, but the dice keep you focused on just a few each turn. That's clever! And while the game is too long, it at least has a length that gives the player plenty of runway for making something happen.

It's not perfect, of course. It really is too long, and I think that's one reason it has proven a hit on BGA and Yucata.de: it plays REALLY well async. And while it does okay with the castle-building feeling it's a pretty drab theme. But this is still a fun game, and one that has proven quite influential over the last 10-15 years.
